text: INFORM partners believe that the availability of shared analysis of crises
label: BODY

text: and disasters can lead to better coordination of actors and better outcomes
label: BODY

text: for at-risk and affected people. Specifically, INFORM creates a space and
label: BODY

text: process for shared analysis that can support joint strategy development,
label: BODY

text: planning and action to prevent, prepare for, respond to and recover from
label: BODY

text: crises. This can bring together development, humanitarian and other actors
label: BODY

text: to manage risk and respond better when crises do occur.
label: BODY

text: This report sets out INFORM’s vision for a suite of products to support
label: BODY

text: decision-making that are easy to use and open to everyone. This vision
label: BODY

text: involves bringing scientific rigour to the process of analysing crises and
label: BODY

text: pooling expertise to develop shared methodologies. By working together, we
label: BODY

text: can reduce the investments required by individual organisations, assure the
label: BODY

text: quality of our analysis and make it available for the common good.
label: BODY

text: INFORM products help improve the quality of evidence for decisions made
label: BODY

text: at every stage of the crisis management cycle from prevention to response.
label: BODY

text: In this report, you’ll find the latest results of the INFORM Severity, INFORM
label: BODY

text: Risk and INFORM Climate Change indexes, and analysis of past, current
label: BODY

text: and potential future global crisis trends.

label: BODY

text: Analysis of the number of countries in each WHO region in each risk class of the DPM for 5 different acute syndromes
label: BODY

text: Preparedness Metric (DPM) is a composite measure
label: BODY

text: of health emergency risks for 196 countries. It aims to
label: BODY

text: inform countries of their preparedness status and support
label: BODY

text: prioritization and implementation of specific actions to
label: BODY

text: improve their capacities. The DPM is based on the INFORM
label: BODY

text: The dynamism of the DPM is achieved through frequently
label: BODY

text: updated indicators (such as epidemic outcomes, seasonal
label: BODY

text: hazards, humanitarian crisis severity) and by presenting
label: BODY

text: risks for 5 different acute syndromes (respiratory, diarrhoeal,
label: BODY

text: haemorrhagic, neurological and acute febrile illness). The
label: BODY

text: DPM is updated quarterly using the latest available data.
label: BODY

text: Risks in the DPM are determined by aggregating indicators
label: BODY

text: vulnerability and capacity), using multisector open-source
label: BODY

text: data to perform up-to-date contextual assessments.
label: BODY

text: Results are scored between 1.0 and 10.0. Low scores
label: BODY

text: represent poor performance (high risk) and high scores
label: BODY

text: represent good performance (low risk). The notion that
label: BODY

text: higher is better is consistently applied across all DPM
label: BODY

text: The results of DPM can be used for global or regional
label: BODY

text: prioritization based on country syndromic risk or any of
label: BODY

text: its components. Countries are exposed to risk differently
label: BODY

text: depending on the type and nature of the communicable
label: BODY

text: disease, current vulnerabilities and existing capacities. Here
label: BODY

text: we use the DPM to measure variation in risk across different
label: BODY

text: syndromes for countries within WHO regions.
label: BODY

text: The password protected DPM Dashboard provides the
label: BODY

text: access point to all DPM results, including country, regional
label: BODY

text: and global profiles. Further information: https://extranet.who.
label: BODY

text: int/sph/dpm. To gain access, please contact ehs@who.int
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The global average severity score of active crises decreased slightly during 2022, as a result of the low severity of several
label: BODY

text: new crises opened during the year.
label: BODY

text: The majority of the active crises in 2022 were in Africa. Both Europe - mainly due to the escalation of the Ukraine conflict -
label: BODY

text: and Asia experienced an increase in the number of active crises.
label: BODY

text: Number of crises by region in 2022
label: BODY

text: Average Severity Index score of all country-level crises during 2022
label: BODY

text: The INFORM Severity Index is released monthly. Here we analyse findings from the Index from calendar year 2022. We
label: BODY

text: focus on country-level crises. We use the terms open and closed for crises that, respectively, met or failed to meet the
label: BODY

text: criteria for inclusion in the Index.
label: BODY

text: Number of crises and their severity in 2022
label: BODY

text: In 2022 the number of crises rose from 115 in January to 136 in December, corresponding to an increase of 18.5%. Most of
label: BODY

text: the crises that were included in the Index in January 2021 (113) were still included in December 2021. In addition:
label: BODY

text: Of the 115 crises open for the whole year, there were 83 which maintained a stable severity category. 10 crises deteriorated
label: BODY

text: and 9 improved. Crises with significant increases in severity in 2022 included: drought in Kenya; violence in the Darfur
label: BODY

text: and Kordofan regions of Sudan and associated refugee flows into Chad; the conflict in Ukraine; and cyclone seasons in
label: BODY

text: Madagascar and Mozambique. Several migration and displacement situations also deteriorated markedly, including in
label: BODY

text: Costa Rica, Ecuador, Libya and Malaysia.
label: BODY

text: Number of crises in the INFORM Severity Index 2022
label: HH3

label: BODY

text: There is a strong correlation between a country’s risk and the severity of a crisis that occurs there. The higher the risk level
label: BODY

text: of a country, the more likely it is to have a severe crisis.

text: Risk predicts the likelihood of a crisis and its severity
label: H3

text: Here we compare the INFORM Risk Index and INFORM Severity Index results. While the Risk Index can tell us about the
label: BODY

text: structural risk of crisis in a country and how it evolves over time, the Severity Index tells us how this risk ultimately translates
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: •	 Almost all crises happened in countries classified as Medium to Very High risk.
label: BODY

text: •	 No countries in the Very Low risk category experienced a crisis.

text: Here we analyse trends in the INFORM Risk Index over the last 10 years of releases (2014-2023). The INFORM Risk Index
label: BODY

text: can be interpreted as the structural risk relating to humanitarian crises. Therefore, it changes quite slowly over time and long-
label: BODY

text: term trends can offer insight into how the structural factors that result in crises are changing over time. Over the last 10 years,
label: BODY

text: we can see some large scale changes in the distribution of risk globally.
label: BODY

text: Over the last ten years, there has been a general increase in the risk of humanitarian crises at global level. While there has
label: BODY

text: been an improvement in coping capacity, this has been negated by large increases in the number of people exposed to
label: BODY

text: hazards, and to their vulnerability. In other words, while development of institutions and infrastructure has helped decrease
label: BODY

text: risks, this has not kept pace with the increased exposure to natural hazards and conflict, combined with socioeconomic
label: BODY

text: challenges. Conflict, displacement and shocks like Covid-19 crisis were important drivers of increasing crisis risks in the last
label: BODY

text: Globally, crisis risk is increasing, despite improvements
label: H3

text: Climate change will increase crisis risks. Under more pessimistic scenarios for
label: BODY

text: greenhouse gas emissions and socio-economic development, by 2050, more
label: BODY

text: than 1.6 billion people will be living in countries experiencing large increases in
label: BODY

text: the risk of humanitarian crises and disasters (>0.3 point increase in risk score).
label: BODY

text: The number of countries classified as having ‘high’ or ‘very high’ crisis risk will
label: BODY

text: More than 5.5 billion people – almost double the number today – will be living
label: BODY

text: in these countries, which today account for almost all humanitarian crises, and
label: BODY

text: in 2022 resulted in 274 million people in need of humanitarian assistance and
label: BODY

text: The number of people living in ‘very high’ crisis risk countries will roughly triple
label: BODY

text: Even under more optimistic scenarios, there will be significant increases in the
label: BODY

text: number of people annually affected by crises and the costs of helping them as

label: BODY

text: Africa and low income countries will be worst affected
label: H3

text: by increasing climate change-related crisis risk
label: H3

text: Crisis and disaster risks will increase in all regions, regardless of climate and socio-economic scenarios.
label: BODY

text: However, certain regions – especially Africa – will be worst affected. The countries likely to be hit hardest are generally located
label: BODY

text: in Western, Southern and Eastern Africa. Other regions of Africa, Central and South America, and Western and Southern Asia
label: BODY

text: Lower income countries will be worst affected. While higher income countries may be able to absorb increases in risk, more
label: BODY

text: than 70% of countries with large predicted increases will not have the resources to cope. This will especially be
label: BODY

text: the case in low and lower-middle income countries, particularly in Africa.
label: BODY

text: Without increased efforts and resources to reduce vulnerability and increase coping capacity in these countries, they will face
label: BODY

text: significant increases in crisis-related human and economic losses, which will further set back development.
label: BODY

text: Change in risk by sub-region 2050 (pessimistic scenario RCP8.5-SSP3)
label: BODY

text: Analysing past and future risk trends of individual countries
label: BODY

text: can help us understand how well placed they are to cope
label: BODY

text: with future crisis risks. Here we compare risk trends over
label: BODY

text: the last 10 years from the INFORM Risk Index with the
label: BODY

text: vulnerability gap in 2050 from INFORM Climate Change.
label: BODY

text: The vulnerability gap represents the amount of adaptation
label: BODY

text: (vulnerability reduction, coping capacity increase) that will
label: BODY

text: be required to maintain the current level of risk. We can
label: BODY

text: identify two groups of countries of interest.
label: BODY

text: •	 Firstly (Group 1), countries that have struggled with
label: BODY

text: increases in crisis risk over the last ten years AND are
label: BODY

text: facing high vulnerability gaps in the future as a result of
label: BODY

text: climate change. These countries will require particularly
label: BODY

text: high adaptation efforts to mitigate future crisis risks.
label: BODY

text: •	 Secondly, (Group 2), countries that are facing a high
label: BODY

text: vulnerability gap in the future but have made reductions
label: BODY

text: in crisis risk over the last decade. This could suggest that
label: BODY

text: these countries are on a good risk reduction trajectory,
label: BODY

text: although they will require continued improvements to

text: Risk increase in Africa and low income
label: BODY

text: From a comparison between regions and income groups
label: BODY

text: of recent past and future risk trends, several points
label: BODY

text: •	 On average, countries in Asia and Oceania were able
label: BODY

text: to reduce their crisis risk over the last decade. If these
label: BODY

text: countries continue their progression, they will have
label: BODY

text: less difficulty facing the increasing risks that come with
label: BODY

text: climate change. However, where climate adaptation
label: BODY

text: strategies are weak, this progress could be negated by
label: BODY

text: •	 Despite some improvements in coping capacity,
label: BODY

text: Africa and low income countries largely failed to tackle
label: BODY

text: increasing crisis risks in the last decade. 6 out of 10
label: BODY

text: countries with largest increases in risk during last 10
label: BODY

text: •	 Africa and low income countries are worst affected by
label: BODY

text: climate-related crisis risks. This is true in terms of both
label: BODY

text: the likely increase in risk and the highest vulnerability
label: BODY

text: gap. The latter represents the amount of vulnerability
label: BODY

text: reduction and coping capacity increase that would
label: BODY

text: be required to maintain the current level of crisis risk.
label: BODY

text: Therefore, they will require the largest investments
label: BODY

text: in crisis prevention and risk management to avoid
label: BODY

text: potentially devastating risk increases in future.
label: BODY

text: Climate change mitigation and sustainable agriculture reduce future aid needs
label: BODY

text: The results of this analysis show how different climate change and agricultural practices affect future crisis severity and
label: BODY

text: funding requirements. High greenhouse gas emissions scenarios combined with non-sustainable agricultural practices
label: BODY

text: lead to significant future increases in drought-related crisis severity and needs in Ethiopia. Conversely, more moderate
label: BODY

text: greenhouse gas emissions and sustainable agriculture lead to more modest increases, comparable with current conditions.
label: BODY

text: Improving and implementing climate policies that focus on mitigation and reduction of carbon emissions and agricultural
label: BODY

text: policies that focus on sustainable practices will therefore have substantial positive consequences on food security and future
label: BODY

text: Impact of the assessed scenarios on the INFORM Severity Index
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Quantifying future crisis severity in Ethiopia
label: H3

text: Scenarios assessed and their impacts on people in need (PIN), funding requirements and
label: BODY

text: The current drought in Ethiopia, the worst since 1984, coupled with the Russian invasion of Ukraine are estimated to have
label: BODY

text: increased the number of food insecure in the drought-affected regions from 0.3M people in February 2022 to 12M in
label: BODY

text: February 2023. The resulting 2022 Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) had 3.09B USD in requirements, about double the
label: BODY

text: amount allocated in each of the past 5 years. The Drought Response Plan (DRP), which represents 1.66B USD of the HRP,
label: BODY

text: targeted 17M people, of which 9.9B were facing Crisis, Emergency, or Famine (High acute malnutrition or higher). About 98
label: BODY

text: USD is allocated per person facing high acute malnutrition or higher.
label: BODY

text: The European Union Horizon 2020 funded project RECEIPT (Remote climate effects and their impact on European
label: BODY

text: sustainability, policy and trade) acts to assess remote climate change impacts on a variety of European risks including those
label: BODY

text: related to agriculture and food production, finance, foreign cooperation and development, global manufacturing chains, and
label: BODY

text: coastal infrastructure. These risks in RECEIPT are assessed using a concept called storylines, i.e., physically self-consistent
label: BODY

text: cause-effect pathways of past events or plausible future events to evaluate the effects of a wide variety of factors, including
label: BODY

text: those related to climate change hazards, climate change adaptation measures, and socioeconomics.
label: BODY

text: Storyline development and the INFORM Severity Index
label: BODY

text: In this storyline, a team from the Risk Assessment and Adaptation Strategies division at the Euro-Mediterranean Center
label: BODY

text: on Climate Change explored the extent to which food crises may become more severe under future climate change is
label: BODY

text: explored with the aim to understand how food crises can be prevented by food security policies and European development
label: BODY

text: co-operations and development aid. The role of climate and population change is considered using FAO food security
label: BODY

text: projections (RCP4.5-TSS and RCP-8.5-SSS) and UN population projections. The number of food insecure people is
label: BODY

text: integrated into the INFORM Severity framework which can be used to provide guidance for decisions regarding humanitarian
label: BODY

text: Quantifying future changes in crisis severity and funding requirements
label: BODY

text: In a food insecurity crisis, INFORM Severity Index considers people in need (PIN) of humanitarian assistance as people
label: BODY

text: under stress levels 3, 4 and 5, which according to the (IPC, 2004) classifications are in a situation of crisis (3), emergency (4)
label: BODY

text: and famine (5). In this analysis, the impact of climate change and agricultural practices on drought-related crisis needs are
label: BODY

text: assessed. The number of people in need are estimated and are integrated into the INFORM Severity Index, to understand
label: BODY

text: possible future changes in crisis severity. An estimate of drought response funding requirements is made based on the per
label: BODY

text: drought event prior to the conflict in
label: BODY
